required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of 3mA HD-tDCS on Associative and Working Memory in Cognitively Intact Older Adults

brief_summary.textblock: As we age, a number of factors can reduce our cognitive (or thinking) abilities. This study will evaluate whether transcranial electrical stimulation (TES), which uses small amounts of electricity to modulate brain functioning, can improve cognitive abilities. Here, the effects of TES on working memory, learning, and memory, will be evaluated in a group of healthy older adults.

detailed_description.textblock:
The primary objective is to investigate the cognitive effects of high definition anodal tDCS (HD-tDCS; anode at center electrode) at 3 mA (for 20 minutes) on learning, memory, and working memory. Participants will be randomized to active or sham stimulation and will complete a series of cognitive tests both during and after stimulation.
Tolerability and blinding will also be evaluated using standard side effect questionnaires.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Total Error
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is an ecologically relevant measure of object location association memory. The OLTT requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a black screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Total Score is the sum of error for all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Average Error
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is a measure of object location association memory. The OLTT requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a blank screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Score is the average error across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Average Time to Respond
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is a measure of object location association memory. The OLTT requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a blank screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Cued Recall Total Error
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Cued Recall, participants are shown the "room" or environment on the screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Total Score is the sum of error for all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Cued Recall Average Error
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Cued Recall, participants are shown the "room" or environment on the screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Score is the average error across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Cued Recall Average Time to Respond
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Cued Recall, participants are shown the "room" or environment on the screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Recognition Total Correct
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Recognition, participants are asked to select the correct location of an object from three options on the screen. Recognition total is the number of correct selections on all 15 trials. Higher scores represent better performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Recognition Average Time to Respond
primary_outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Recognition, participants are asked to select the correct location of an object from three options on the screen. Recognition Average Response Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

primary_outcome.measure: Performance (d') on a Simple Attention (0-back) Test
primary_outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

primary_outcome.measure: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (2-back) Test
primary_outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

primary_outcome.measure: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (Semantic 2-back) Test
primary_outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During Semantic-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

primary_outcome.measure: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
primary_outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.

primary_outcome.measure: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (Semantic 2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
primary_outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During Semantic 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.

secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to estimate which group they were in (i.e., active or sham).

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Headache Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Neck Pain Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Scalp Pain Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Burning Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Skin Redness Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Concentration Changes Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Mood Changes Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
secondary_outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

arm_group.description: Participants will receive "real" HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session.
Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session.

intervention.description: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Individuals with intact cognitive functioning.
2. Participants will be age 50 or older.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Individuals with a documented history of cognitive impairment.
2. A history of serious mental illness (e.g., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, axis 2 disorders)
3. Sensory or motor impairments that limit the ability to take part in the study
4. A significant history or current use of alcohol or drug abuse/dependence
5. Those who are currently pregnant (if there is a question of pregnancy, pregnancy tests will be available for participants at no charge)
6. Participants with an Mini Mental State Examination score <24 at screening.

facility.name: University of Michigan - Department of Psychiatry

reference.citation: Brunoni AR, Amadera J, Berbel B, Volz MS, Rizzerio BG, Fregni F. A systematic review on reporting and assessment of adverse effects associated with transcranial direct current stimulation. Int J Neuropsychopharmacol. 2011 Sep;14(8):1133-45. doi: 10.1017/S1461145710001690. Epub 2011 Feb 15. Review.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Two participants were excluded after consent due to failing the tDCS safety screen. One participant endorsed a skin condition with lesions at site of electrode placement. One participant disclosed a prior head injury.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Machine malfunction; did not reach 3 mA

baseline.population: One participant was a statistical outlier for several behavioral measures and was excluded from baseline data and all analyses

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Ethnicity (NIH/OMB)
Race (NIH/OMB)

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Region of Enrollment
Mini-Mental State Examination
measure.description: The Mini Mental-State Examination is a 30-item global cognitive screen. Scores range from 0-30 with higher scores represent better performances and scores 23 and below are suggestive of cognitive impairment.
measure.population: Participants were not screened if an MMSE was completed within the past six months as part of their involvement with the Michigan Alzheimer's Disease Center (n = 2)

measure.title: Education
Impedance
measure.description: The first impedance reading averaged across all five electrodes. The unit measured is in "Quality Units" as produced by the Soterix transcranial direct current stimulation machine, which is a proprietary measurement of impedance. Lower values represent less impedance.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Total Error
measure.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is an ecologically relevant measure of object location association memory. The OLTT requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a black screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Total Score is the sum of error for all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

analysis.groups_desc: We used a multivariate statistic to compare OLTT means (Free Recall Total Error, Free Recall Average Error, Cued Recall Total Error, Cued Recall Average Error, Recognition Total Correct) at baseline (Version B) to post HD-tDCS OLTT means (Version C), by groups (active vs. sham). The overall statistic represents the simultaneous comparison of baseline OLTT measures to post HD-tDCS OLTT measures.
analysis.p_value_desc: Reported p-value represents Time (baseline to post-tDCS) x Condition (Active or Sham) interaction for all OLTT Accuracy Measures. If the multivariate statistic is not significant no univariate statistical analyses are completed.
analysis.method_desc: repeated measures (OLTT baseline and post-tDCS); between-subjects (active vs. sham)

outcome.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Average Error
outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is a measure of object location association memory. The OLTT requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a blank screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Score is the average error across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent better performance.

measure.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Free Recall Average Time to Respond
measure.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) is a measure of object location association memory. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Free Recall, participants are given a blank screen and asked to touch the area of the screen an object was located. Average Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

analysis.groups_desc: A Repeated Measures ANOVA was used to compare baseline OLTT (Version B) to post-tDCS OLTT (Version C) across the treatment groups (Active vs. Sham). The multivariate analyses included OLTT Response Times (i.e., Free Recall Average Response Time, Cued Recall Average Response Time, Recognition Average Response Time)
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistic represents the interaction between Time (baseline to post-tDCS) by Condition (Active vs. Sham).

analysis.groups_desc: Univariate analysis of the OLTT Free Recall Average Time to Respond following significant multivariate repeated measures ANOVA comparing baseline OLTT (Version B) to post-tDCS OLTT (Version C) across the treatment groups (Active vs. Sham).

outcome.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Cued Recall Total Error

Higher scores represent better performance.

outcome.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Recognition Average Time to Respond
outcome.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Recognition, participants are asked to select the correct location of an object from three options on the screen. Recognition Average Response Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Object Location Touchscreen Task (Version C) Recognition Average Time to Respond
measure.description: The Object Location Touchscreen Task (OLTT) requires participants to learn and recall the location of 15 object-location associations. Memory is evaluated using a touchscreen monitor, which allows for the continuous measurement of memory accuracy (i.e., distance from targeted location). During the Recognition, participants are asked to select the correct location of an object from three options on the screen. Recognition Average Response Time is the average latency to respond across all 15 trials. Lower scores represent faster responses.

analysis.groups_desc: Univariate analysis of the OLTT Recognition Average Time to Respond following significant multivariate repeated measures ANOVA comparing baseline OLTT (Version B) to post-tDCS OLTT (Version C) across the treatment groups (Active vs. Sham).

outcome.title: Performance (d') on a Simple Attention (0-back) Test
outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Performance (d') on a Simple Attention (0-back) Test
measure.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

outcome.title: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (2-back) Test
outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (2-back) Test
measure.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.

outcome.title: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (Semantic 2-back) Test
outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During Semantic-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.
outcome.population: missing data for eleven participants (5 Active; 6 Sham) due to Eprime miscalculation

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Performance (d') on a Working Memory (Semantic 2-back) Test
measure.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During Semantic-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. Higher scores represent better discriminability.
measure.population: missing data for eleven participants (5 Active; 6 Sham) due to Eprime miscalculation

outcome.title: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.
outcome.population: missing data for 12 participants: 11 2-back (5 Active; 6 sham) due to Eprime miscalculation & one 0-back (Active)

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
measure.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is the exact same as two items ago. Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.
measure.population: missing data for 12 participants: 11 2-back (5 Active; 6 sham) due to Eprime miscalculation & one 0-back (Active)

outcome.title: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (Semantic 2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
outcome.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During Semantic 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

group.title: Sham HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will undergo the exact same procedures as the active group but will receive sham stimulation for a single session. Sham HD-tDCS: Participants will receive sham HD-tDCS

measure.title: Calculated Working Memory Performance Accounting for Simple Attention (Semantic 2-back d' Minus 0-back d')
measure.description: The n-back is a well validated measure of working memory. During 0-back, participants are asked to respond by pressing a key when the picture on the screen is the same as the given target (e.g., a cow). During Semantic 2-back, participants are asked to respond when a picture shown is in the same semantic category as the picture two items ago (e.g., both fruits). Discriminability (d') is a measure of signal detection that accounts for signal to noise ratio. By subtracting the 0-back d', the calculated score represents a more pure working memory measure. Scores closer to zero or positive represent better working memory performance.

analysis.groups_desc: A Multivariate ANOVA was used to compare Active vs. Sham groups on discriminability measures (i.e. 0-back d', 2-back d', semantic 2-back d') and calculated working memory measures (i.e., 2-back d' minus 0-back d', semantic 2-back d' minus 0-back d').

outcome.title: Blinding in Total Sample
outcome.description: Participants were asked to estimate which group they were in (i.e., active or sham).

group.title: Active HD-tDCS
group.description: Participants will receive “real” HD-tDCS (3 milliamps for 20 minutes) for a single session. Active HD-tDCS: Participants will receive active HD-tDCS at 3mA for 20 minutes

measure.title: Blinding in Total Sample
measure.description: Participants were asked to estimate which group they were in (i.e., active or sham).

analysis.groups_desc: Chi-squared tests were conducted to determine group differences in actual condition assignment vs. estimated/perceived condition

outcome.title: Frequency of Endorsement (%) for Headache Item in Active and Sham Participants Undergoing HD-tDCS Session
outcome.description: The side effects were assessed using a modified version of Brunoni et al. (2011) questionnaire. Participants rated common sensory experiences on a scale of "None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe".

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
